title: Chinas 70 year parade economic military might
story: Share this article    What if Karl Marx travelled through time to see today's China?'If Marx came back I think he would say that it is not socialist. That is, it is not moving in the historical direction of communism but has settled into a rather rigid state capitalism with strong authoritarian elements,â€™ Crane said.Another break from Mao was the end of one-man rule.Deng backed a system of â€˜collectiveâ€™ leadership and orderly succession following his death in 1997.Jiang Zemin served two five-year terms as president, and his successor Hu Jintao complied with the new tradition.But Xi has turned back the clock to become the most powerful leader since Mao.Like the â€˜Great Helmsmanâ€™ before him, Xi has benefited from a state media-crafted cult of personality.The country's founder had â€˜Mao Zedong Thought.â€™         Residents stand behind the barricade line to watch floats taking part in a parade to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the founding of Communist China in Beijing         Balloons are seen above performers at the end of the parade marking the 70th founding anniversary of People's Republic of China         A child holding a Chinese national flag squats as residents watch floats taking part in a parade to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the founding of Communist China in Beijing         Residents use smartphone to film a colorful float carrying the words 'Long live motherland' during a parade to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the founding of Communist China in Beijing on Tuesday         People wave Chinese flags during celebrations marking the 70th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China in Beijing on Tuesday         The event marks the anniversary of the Oct. 1, 1949, announcement of the founding of the People's Republic of China by then-leader Mao ZedongThe current leader enshrined â€˜Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Eraâ€™ in the constitution.Mao had the â€˜Little Red Book.â€™Xi has his 21st-century version - an app dubbed â€˜Study Xi,â€™ featuring his teachings.Xi has overseen a crackdown on graft that has punished more than 1.5 million party officials - a popular move among ordinary citizens but seen by observers as a chance to purge rivals.Xi could be here to stay with the removal of presidential term limits.The opening of the economy has not been accompanied by political reforms.China marked another anniversary this year, one that the party made sure was not commemorated - the 30th anniversary of the brutal repression of pro-democracy protesters at Tiananmen Square.The government has even tightened its grip on society under Xi, detaining activists, stepping up internet censorship, and refusing to free dissident and Nobel peace laureate Liu Xiaobo even while he was dying of cancer.Authorities are increasingly using China's development of technology such as facial recognition to monitor citizens.In the northwest region of Xinjiang, the mostly Muslim Uighur ethnic group has learned the hard way what it means to run afoul of the government.More than one million people there are said to have been placed in internment camps in the name of combating terrorism.Â

title: Reggae superstar Bob Marley honoured English Heritage blue plaque
story: Share this article Though he gave a different address, it is speculated that Marley did so to prevent the police from searching the house in Oakley Street - where his band-mates were staying - for drugs.Other anecdotal reports from witnesses suggested the house was the band's headquarters and Marley's primary address.The plaque was unveiled by Rastafarian writer and poet Benjamin Zephaniah and introduced by historian and broadcaster David Olusoga, who is also a blue plaque panel member.         A woman walks past an English Heritage blue plague for Bob Marley.Â The plaque was unveiled by Rastafarian writer and poet Benjamin Zephaniah and introduced by historian and broadcaster David Olusoga         Artist Keith Baugh shows old photographs of Bob Marley at the unveiling of an English Heritage blue plague for the singer, at his former home in Chelsea         Marley left Jamaica at the end of 1976, eventually spending two years in England and completing Exodus as well as follow-up album Kaya (pictured at the Hammersmith Odeon, London in 1977)Zephaniah, said: 'It's very difficult to say what Bob Marley would have said about this plaque, but he did once say, Live for yourself, you will live in vain, live for others, and you will live again, so I'm quite sure he would say that this is for his people and his music.'Blue plaques commemorate the link between a location and an inidual who was regarded as 'eminent' in their field.Their achievements should have made an 'exceptional impact in terms of public recognition', and they must have been dead for at least 20 years.Other musicians to have received the honour include John Lennon, Freddie Mercury and Mozart.Â During his time at the house, Marley and his bandmates often played football at the pitches in nearby Battersea Park.Â Marley left Jamaica at the end of 1976, eventually spending two years in England and completing Exodus as well as follow-up album Kaya.Exodus stayed on the album charts in the UK for 56 weeks in a row, spawning the hit singles Exodus, Waiting in Vain, Jamming and One Love.The Jamaican icon was also arrested during his stay in London and convicted for possessing a small quantity of cannabis.Â Â Â Â Â        Installed on buildings around London by English Heritage, the blue plaques celebrate the link between famous and influential figures and the places where they lived or worked in London. Pictured, some of those receiving the plaques this yearMarley performed at theÂ Crystal Palace BowlÂ on June 7, 1980 while gravely ill. It would prove to be his last appearance in the UK, with the legendary musician dying less then a year later.Â Â Â The cultural icon already has two blue plaques in London, including at a house he stayed at in Neasden, north west London, andÂ Flat 34 Ridgmount Gardens in central London, the place where he first stayed in the capital.Mr Olusoga,Â English Heritage trustee and blue plaques panel member, said: 'Bob Marley was the first superstar to emerge from the developing world. More than a brilliant musician, he became a cultural icon who blazed a trail for other black artists.'Traveller and diplomat Gertrude Bell and novelist Angela Carter are among several other famous figures commemorated with blue plaques this year.Mr Olusoga added: 'From engineering to music, this year's blue plaques remind us of the enormous range of human achievement.'All of our blue plaque recipients called London home, at least for a while, and our plaques are a testament to the creativity and variety of this city.'Â

title: Stormzy congratulates UCL student getting 10 000 word Hip Hop dissertation
story: Share this article          Amarie tweeted the result of her degree (top) and Stormzy replied thanking her and congratulating himÂ She added: 'It was still so shocking and heart-warming to see that he actually did though.'Amarie's dissertation was titled 'That's Not Me: An interdisciplinary analysis of the black male identity in British hip-hop.'Part-time DJ Amarie always wanted to write her dissertation on hip-hop, but honed in on her topic after reading a paper called 'How Hip-Hop holds Blacks back.'She said: 'It portrayed the genre and the artists in such a one-sided way.'In this day and age, we're seeing hip-hop artists start businesses, charities and change peoples' lives for the better.         Amarie (pictured above) was working part time at Sony Music while studying for her degreeÂ 'I knew there was another side to the argument and I wanted to explore it.'Amarie, who held down a job at Sony Music during her studies, set out to change the often negative narrative surrounding black hip-hop artists.She added: 'From school to adulthood, there are so many systematic hurdles faced by black people and ethnic minorities in Britain that mean they shouldn't be successful or even be at top universities like UCL.'That was probably the most interesting but also the most difficult to read about, being black British.'Reflecting on the mammoth task of writing a dissertation, Amarie advised fellow students to pick a topic they enjoy.She said: 'It's hours in the library and a lot of reading. Whatever your course is, just try and pick something that will keep you wanting to read and write about it. 10,000 words on any topic ain't easy.'Â

title: Doctor 27 told leave country week face DEPORTED Taiwan
story: Share this article Miss Chiang had been on a student visa from 2006 until earlier this year, but needed to apply for a working visa to remain.Her application began in June and included receiving a sponsorship certificate from Health Education England, but the issue that stands to cost her the right to stay did not emerge until August this year.The Home Office set a threshold to prove she was self-supporting, which was to have at least Â£945 in a bank account during the 90-day period of her application.         Mu-Chun Chiang (left) as a child playing in the snow in the UK. She has now been asked to leave the UKWhile the balance on her current account had fallen below Â£945, she says she did have more than this amount in her savings account.However, she only submitted the current account statements, as she was under the impression that the threshold only needed to be met at the end of each month.The Home Office rejected her application, but she appealed within days with statements proving her savings account did have enough money in it throughout the 90 days.Miss Chiang said: 'I failed to realise they meant at no point, not even one hour of the day, was my money allowed to drop below the Â£945. This was a genuine misinterpretation of the rules.'Despite this, she picked up a letter on September 27 informing her that she was facing deportation within seven days.         Mu-Chun Chiang (pictured as an infant)Â has lived in the UK since 2006, when she moved to Cambridge from Taiwan to study, and before that had lived with her parents in Glasgow between 1997 and 2002It was dated 19 September and was delivered on 25 September, but Miss Chiang missed it because she was working shifts in hospital. The Home Office now insists she doesn't face removal.She said: 'It feels like they are treating me as a criminal. I have had to stop working - I am meant to be on call and my employers are trying to get cover.'With how the NHS is, I don't know why they won't take into consideration my appeal.'More than 10,000 people have signed a petition calling on the Home Office to reverse its decision, attracting support from fellow doctors in the UK and abroad.Miss Chiang said: 'Never have I really thought of myself as a really valuable asset with the right to stay. But I really enjoy my job, and everybody knows there is a shortage of GPs.'These sorts of rules from the Home Office need to be revisited - I am meeting a lawyer on Monday to see what my options are, but a lot of doctors will just give up and go home.'Satbir Singh, chief executive of the Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants said:Â  'At a time when our NHS is under immense strain and crying out for more doctors, kicking out a young doctor trained to work in the NHS just defies basic common sense.''Our immigration system is dysfunctional, complicated and inhumane.'That someone can be threatened with detention and removal because of a small technical mistake in a visa application highlights the urgent need for the system to be rebuilt from ground up so that people who move here are treated fairly and with humanity.'In a statement, a Home Office spokesman said: 'All visa applications are considered on their inidual merits and in line with the immigration rules.'Ms Chiang did not provide the evidence required to be granted a visa but we are in contact with her and are discussing the options available to her.'Â

title: Athletics fans slam stadium Doha World Championships
story: Share this article Mother of silver GB medallist Dina Asher-Smith, who came second in the 100m sprint in front of a near-empty stadium on Sunday, has slammed the governing body.She tweeted that she had seen more people turn out to the England Athletics championships in Bedford.Â Â Dobbin added:Â 'In Berlin (at last year's European Championships) I didn't look up into the crowds because I didn't want to get nervous. Here, I didn't want to look in case I was disappointed.'I watched Dina's victory lap and that was a bit heart-breaking because what she did was insane and there was no-one there.'I feel like she was robbed of that moment. But that shouldn't take away from how good the athletes are performing.Â Â France's decathlon world champion Kevin Mayer has branded the championships in Qatar a 'disaster'.Today the 400m men's heats took place with barely anyone in the crowds.Â Â                                                       Champion heptathlon Denise Lewis and fans on Twitter have slammed the empty stadiumsÂ But IAAF chief executive John Ridgeon has said he believes diplomatic tension in the region is to blame.Â Defending the decision to award the games to Qatar, he said: 'You have to understand the political challenges this country faces, which was never envisaged.'You must remember, when this event was awarded (to Qatar) six or seven years ago it was always positioned as a celebration of athletics in the Middle East.'Clearly geopolitics has shifted since, there's a blockade now on this country from the surrounding countries.'Officials also argued the beginning of the Qatari working week and conflicting TV scheduling was to blame.Â Â Â Â Â Two years ago, an air, land and sea blockade was imposed on Qatar by Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Egypt over their possible ties to Iran.         Team GB's Beth Dobbins said it was 'heart-breaking' her teammate Dina Asher-Smith (pictured) got her silver medal - only to be met with empty stands         Local spectators are pictured in the stands in Doha todayÂ          Organisers have scrambled around to try to fix the problem, offering tickets to thousands of migrant workers from Africa and India free of charge. Pictured todayÂ Organisers have scrambled around to try to fix the problem, offering tickets to thousands of migrant workers from Africa and India free of charge.Â Commentators have claimed the audiences have been made up mainly of free guests and journalists.Â Â Â Mr Ridgeon added in defence of the IAAF:Â 'I can't emphasise enough how hard we're working the Local Organising Committee to make it better.'The next four years for us is all about growing athletics, and actually going to new parts of the world is important in that.Â 'The crowd is important, but many athletes are having positive experiences and the athletics is stunning.'We will, at the end of the championships, absolutely review what's happened here, decide what works for future and what doesn't. You have to keep challenging yourself.'Â Â          Demish Gaye of Jamaica and Michael Norman of the USA compete in the 400m heats in Doha today with stands nearly empty in the backgroundÂ Â

story: Share this article He went on: 'Knowing for the entirety of the flight that my bag is lying on the tarmac back in Munich was pretty annoying.'Â The error was especially irritating as he had arrived at the airport more than two hours early and was one of the first passengers to board, he said.Â The plane was still at the terminal when he spotted the bag, he added, meaning it would not have had to turn back to retrieve his luggage.Â Â          The Lufthansa passenger was eventually reunited with the suitcase (pictured) nearly 36 hours after it was abandoned in MunichÂ Responding to his tweet, Lufthansa blamed the error on an 'outage of the baggage system in Frankfurt' - even though the flight took off 200 miles away in Munich.Â Once he arrived in Manchester, Karn filed a lost baggage complaint and the bag was eventually shipped over on another flight.Â On Monday night he posted a picture of the suitcase and said he was 'happy to be reunited with it'.Â Â 'To the people who laughed, I shall join you once Iâ€™m unpacked,' he joked.Â 'Hope none of you have to watch your bag being left behind and not be able to do anything about it,' he said.Â

title: Indian PM declares country open defecation free
story: Share this article However, experts are sceptical over his claims, citing data from rural as well as urban areas.'A lot of latrines have been constructed from 2014 to 2018. Latrine ownership increased from about 35 percent to about 70 percent,' said Sangita Vyas from the Research Institute for Compassionate Economics (RICE).'That increase did accelerate the reduction of open defecation but in December 2018 we estimated about half of people in the states of Bihar, Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan still defecated in the open,' she told AFP, doubting that the shortfall has been made up since.Many of the toilets that have been constructed are without a water connection and even when they are connected, cultural barriers stop many Indians from using them, experts say.       The Indian government says it has built more than 100 million toilets, particularly in rural areas, a major public health issue in the country of 1.3 billion people. He made his 'latrines for all' pledge when he first assumed office in 2014 and is hailing the project's success as India celebrates the 150th anniversary of the birth of independence hero Mahatma Gandhi, a sanitation championThe announcement will come one week afterÂ a 10-year-old boy and a 12-year-old girl were beaten to death for defecating in the open, underlining the violence sometimes unleashed to enforce Prime Minister Narendra Modi's flagship cleanliness drive.The children from the Dalit community, India's lowest social caste previously known as 'untouchables', were on their way to their grandfather's house in the Shivpuri district in the central state of Madhya Pradesh on Wednesday.'It was early morning and they had stopped to attend to nature's call' when they were attacked, police inspector general Raja Babu Singh told AFP by phone on Thursday.'The kids were taken to the hospital but they succumbed to their injuries.'Two brothers had been arrested, one of whom appeared to be 'mentally unsound', Singh added.Â Â

title: Britains envoy New Zealand rubs noses Maori leader
story: Share this article Many scholars now believe the Maori were probably only making a ceremonial challenge to Cook's men.Â Maori tribe Rongowhakaata recently described the first encounter in blunt terms: 'After only being here for two hours, Cook and his crew had trespassed, terrorised, killed and stolen from us.'Â The British High Commission said the exact wording of Ms Clarke's speech to Maori leaders today would remain private.Â          Laura Clarke (left) wipes her tears after meeting the Maori elder (right) in Gisborne. Her words fell short of the full apology that some had demanded from the British royal familyThey were also careful to point out that today's expression from regret came from the UK Government and not from the Queen or royal family.Â Â However, they said Ms Clarke would acknowledge the 'pain' of those first encounters and offer her sympathy to the descendants of those who died.Â Â Britain has also been returning some historic artifacts taken by Cook's crew, including canoe paddles.Â The high commission was careful to point out that Wednesday's expression of regret came from the British government and not from the British monarch, Queen Elizabeth II.Â New Zealand's race relations commissioner Meng Foon, also a former mayor of Gisborne, said Ms Clarke's words were another part of the reconciliation and relationship-building process.Â However, he said that as mayor he had invited the British royal family to come to Wednesday's event but received no response.         British explorer Captain James Cook (pictured in an 18th-century portrait) sighted New Zealand from HMS Endeavour in October 1769 and landed at what he called Poverty BayHe would have liked to have descendants of Queen Victoria meet with descendants of the Maori who were killed and offer them a full apology, he said.Â Â .'It's not the end of the story,' he said of Clarke's speech. 'I believe future generations will demand an apology.'The Maori are involved in a decades-long legal process seeking redress for historic wrongs under New Zealand's founding document, the Treaty of Waitangi.Â The 1840 document was signed on the British side by emissaries of Queen Victoria.Â Dozens of tribes have made settlements worth billions of dollars under its provisions.Â Â Â Captain Cook left New Zealand in early 1770 - naming his departure point Cape Farewell - but returned in 1773 and 1777.Â He was killed in a skirmish with native people in Hawaii in 1779.Â Â

title: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu begins final attempt fend corruption indictment
story: Share this article Israel's attorney general has recommended charging Netanyahu with bribery, fraud and breach of trust in three separate cases.Â Netanyahu has denied any wrongdoing and has said the claims are part of a media-orchestrated witch hunt.Â Â The allegations accuse him of accepting hundreds of thousands of dollars of champagne and cigars from billionaire friends and offering a critical publisher legislation that would weaken his paper's main rival in return for softer treatment.Â Â He is also accused of using his influence to help a wealthy telecom magnate in exchange for favorable coverage on a popular news site.Â Â Netanyahu has continually promised to clear his name in the hearing.Â A team of his lawyers arrived at the Justice Ministry in Jerusalem today to argue that all charges should be dropped.Â His attorney, Amit Haddad, said: 'We are going to present not only the evidence everyone is aware of but also new evidence.Â          Benjamin Netanyahu's pre-indictment hearing on corruption charges began today in Jerusalem. Pictured is Ram Caspi, Netanyahu's lawyer, arriving at the Justice Ministry'We are sure that once we present our findings there will be no choice but to close the case.Â He added: 'We believe and know that at the end of the day all the three cases must be closed.'Â Â Â The sessions are expected to extend over four days. And it could take several weeks for the attorney general to render his final decision.Â However, legal experts say the likelihood of an indictment is very high given the mountains of evidence collected by police over years of investigations and the prosecution's seeming consensus of pursuing a trial.Although Netanyahu would not be required to step down if charged, he will face heavy pressure to do so.Â          President Reuven Rivlin (right) selected Netanyahu last week as the candidate with the best chance of forming a governmentHe hasn't been able to muster the required 61-seat majority in parliament to build a coalition government and faces stiff resistance from those he will need to back him.President Reuven Rivlin selected Netanyahu last week as the candidate with the best chance of forming a government.Â That move came after Rivlin failed to broker a unity government between Netanyahu and Blue and White leader Benny Gantz in recent days.Â A unity government appears to be the preferred option for both sides, but they remain far apart on who should lead it first and what such a constellation would look like.Â          That move came after Rivlin failed to broker a unity government between Netanyahu and Blue and White leader Benny Gantz (pictured) in recent daysNetanyahu and Gantz were set to meet again today before Gantz abruptly cancelled, signaling the likely breakdown of the talks.In such a case, Netanyahu will probably inform the president he cannot form a government. Rivlin will then likely offer a chance to Gantz, who faces equally long odds of doing so.Â If he too doesn't succeed, Rivlin can select another legislator or he can set in motion what would be unprecedented third elections.According to the final official results from the September 17 elections, Blue and White finished first with 33 seats in the 120-seat parliament, just ahead of Netanyahu's Likud with 32 seats.Â Netanyahu edged Gantz, however, 55-54 in the number of lawmakers who recommend him as prime minister, leaving both short of the magic number of 61.Â

title: in it to win it why are we so obsessed with quizzes
story: The return of the classic quiz show Blockbusters reflects our love of knowledge tests. Rae Ritchie looks at why getting the right answer is so addictive, and why getting the wrong answer can be so funnyWhat Q is one of the nationâ€™s favourite pastimes? Nope, itâ€™s not quidditch. Itâ€™s quizzes. We love racking our brains for that obscure bit of knowledge that weâ€™re sure we once heard somewhere. Whether we are in the pub with our mates or at home shouting at the television, the feeling of getting an answer right is addictive. But why do we find quizzes so compelling?A buzz from the buzzerThe very nature of a quiz lures us in. As veteran question writer David Bodycombe observes: â€œIf a question is posed, you canâ€™t help but wonder what the answer is.â€When we get the answer correct, various factors make us want to go back for more. Michelle Tolfrey, a clinical psychologist and member of the Welldoing.org community of therapists, explains: â€œPhysiologically, when we win something, we experience a nice hit of dopamine, which can be quite a euphoric and â€˜buzzyâ€™ feeling to have. As a result, we may want to replicate this again and again to get the same sensation.â€Tolfrey also points out the psychological rewards involved in quizzes. â€œThey can be particularly enjoyable if we are doing them in the context of socialising with peers, where it can help us to feel connected with others and part of something special.â€œAnd there are, of course, lots of other social rewards involved with quizzes, such as receiving praise from others or being given a certain title, prize or accolade that boosts our self esteem.â€Fellow clinical psychologist and Welldoing.org therapist Patapia Tzotzoli agrees that quizzes can meet basic human needs. â€œPeople are creatures of emotion and are motivated by pride and vanity,â€ she says. â€œQuizzes offer a platform where our knowledge is being assessed by our ability to retrieve information quickly while others are watching. Doing so offers us quick gratification and a sense of achievement that nourishes our self-esteem and gains us immediate recognition.â€œIn other words, quizzes offer a setting with the right conditions to feed our need to be important and appreciated for it.â€But if quizzes are so rewarding, why do our brains seem to crack under the pressure of needing to come up with the right answer â€“ and quickly?â€œSometimes anxiety kicks in and interferes with our memory â€“ and consequently our performance,â€ states Tzotzoli. â€œThe more anxious we become, the harder it is to remember the information we are after and we experience what we commonly describe as our â€˜mind going blankâ€™.â€Not quite the answerTimes when a contestantâ€™s mind goes awry make for comedy gold on quiz programmes. On the iconic 80s and 90s show Blockbusters, for instance, participants still had â€œmind going blankâ€ moments despite being given the first letter of the answer. When asked by legendary host Bob Holness â€œWhat D, rhyming with a synonym for defraud, means to decrease in number or grow smaller in size?â€, quizzer Susie somehow managed to come up with shrink (correct answer: dwindle, rhymes with swindle).At other times, contestants stuck to the right letter, but under the pressure of studio lights, got the wrong word. After answering â€œWhat O is the generic word for any living animal or plant, including bacteria or viruses?â€, a young man cringed when he realised that heâ€™d replied orgasm not organism. Contestant Pauline looked even more mortified when the penny dropped that the response to â€œWhat K is a Chinese ceremony of abasement?â€ was kowtow â€“ not Kama Sutra.More such moments follow on the new series of Blockbusters thatâ€™s about to hit our screens on Comedy Central. Host Dara Ã“ Briain is met with laughable responses to questions including â€œWhat Q is a type of pen that is made from a birdâ€™s featherâ€ and â€œWhat N are potatoes when they first come into season?â€ No, the answers are not quail and nugget.As in the original, this latest incarnation features student contestants, although a celebrity special with Strictly Come Dancingâ€™s Stacey Dooley and Oti Mabuse against comedian Josh Widdecombe starts the series off.For us armchair quizzers joining in from our sofas, the Blockbusters style of question has major appeal. As Bodycombe puts it: â€œItâ€™s a clever format because thereâ€™s a clue inherently built into the question, which automatically makes you think you might have a chance of getting it right.â€Bodycombe is spot-on. No matter how smart, we all need a little help. Just try to distinguish between organism and orgasm.What B has a brand new series?The new series of Blockbusters â€“ hosted by Dara Ã“ Briain â€“ hits our screens at 8pm on Thursday 26 September on Comedy Central.

title: question are two heads really better than one
story: Blockbusters, the classic gameshow that pits two players against one, is returning for a second series. So in quizzes â€“ and indeed life â€“ do you get the best results working in a team or flying solo? Abi Smith unpicks the scienceHow good are you at quizzes? Go on, you can be honest. You think youâ€™re pretty good, right? Well, you might have a superior intellect â€“ but then again, you might just be overconfident. â€œThis is known as the Dunning-Kruger effect, which states that the majority of people tend to overestimate their abilities,â€ says Matt Shaw, a performance psychologist at coaching company InnerDrive.â€œInterestingly, this is more pronounced in those with the lowest ability, such as inexperienced players,â€ says Shaw. â€œExperts tend to underestimate their abilities, which is sometimes called â€˜the burden of expertiseâ€™.â€Knowing whether you are the type of person who is burdened with expert knowledge or likely to overegg your skills is the kind of insight that would come in handy when playing Blockbusters â€“ the classic TV gameshow that pits a single player against a team of two students.Recently relaunched on Comedy Central with comedian Dara Ã“ Briain presiding, the game sees contestants making their way across the iconic hexagon-filled game board, answering questions that begin with a particular letter of the alphabet. The format rewards general knowledge, lateral thinking, quick reactions and â€“ in the case of the paired-up players â€“ teamwork.â€œItâ€™s really important that you choose your thinking partner wisely,â€ says Robert Ritchie, whoâ€™s made a career by cultivating positive mindsets and behaviours across different types of teams.Currently head of organisational development at the University of Salford, Ritchie says â€œone head is better than twoâ€ in the idea-creation stages. After that, he says, you can deliberately decide who to bring in and when. â€œIn a quiz format, that process is accelerated. You have to have that initial moment of reaction and decision on your own, otherwise youâ€™ll only ever be going around consensus or groupthink,â€ he adds. Get the right teammate and gameplay can be dazzlingly swift: just check out this pair of Cambridge students trouncing their single opponent.Intriguingly, however, two heads are likely to be better than one even if youâ€™re not both Blockbusting naturals. â€œThere is a quirky phenomenon called the KÃ¶hler effect,â€ says Shaw. â€œThis is when working with other people, the weaker teammate tends to elevate their performance. Not only do people work harder if their partner is outperforming them, they are also more motivated when they know that the teamâ€™s performance relies on them. This is more prominent when team membersâ€™ abilities are similar, like in a quiz.â€ Itâ€™s perhaps no surprise, therefore, that across the two Comedy Central series of Blockbusters, 11 out of 20 have been won by the pair â€“ despite pairs requiring one more correct answer each round than the solo players.Question setter Charlotte Hazzard, who runs the quiz at the historic Grapes pub in Limehouse, London, also believes that two heads are better than one. â€œWhen youâ€™ve got two brains, youâ€™re able to pull on a greater bank of knowledge, and pub quizzes often need quite a wide spread of general knowledge,â€ she says.Knowing the information and having it ready at the right moment are two very different skills, however. Team player Philip fell foul of this when asked: â€œWhat U is something designed for both men and women?â€ His immediate response â€“ underwear â€“ was factually correct but not what the question was looking for. The word Ã“ Briain wanted, of course, was unisex.Thereâ€™s a reason that the first answer that comes into your head wonâ€™t necessarily win you points, according to Shaw. â€œGut responses are essentially shortcuts that help us make decisions quickly and when under pressure. However, theyâ€™re not always accurate. Under stress or pressure (like in a quiz), our focus can become too narrow, meaning we stop searching for alternative answers, which can lead to mistakes,â€ he says.Comedian Josh Widdicombe learned this to his cost on the celebrity edition when he buzzed in too soon on a question about West End musicals, proffering West Side Story as his W answer. This allowed professional dancer and presenter Oti Mabuse to swoop in with the correct response â€“ Wicked â€“ and salvage the point for herself and her presenter teammate, Stacey Dooley.Sometimes though, one head is all it takes. â€œAt the end of the day, if you go with your gut instinct and get it incorrect, youâ€™re more forgiving of yourself than if you hadnâ€™t gone with your gut,â€ says Hazzard, whose quiz is often frequented by the leaseholder of the Grapes pub, Sir Ian McKellen. The other benefit of going it alone is that you donâ€™t need to negotiate the politics of playing in a team. In one of many Blockbuster bust-ups, teammates Manreet and Nyah disagreed on the choice of letter and subsequently lost a point, with Manreet jokingly defecting to their opponentâ€™s side. So, are two heads really better than one? It depends on the problem and the people â€“ and whether you can keep playing nice.What B has a brand new series?The new series of Blockbusters â€“ hosted by Dara Ã“ Briain â€“ hits our screens at 8pm on Thursday 26 September on Comedy Central.

title: glitch by lee rourke review
story: Lee Rourkeâ€™s admirably economical third novel is an intellectually playful exploration of entropy, mutability and chance. Itâ€™s also a moving portrait of a son caring for his ailing mother, and coming to terms with the grief of losing her.After two decades in America, L-J returns home to the UK for a hand operation. On the flight, a near-catastrophic episode of cabin decompression forces him to meditate on his mortality, and the way everything in life is â€œprone to malfunctionâ€ sooner or later. This insight becomes more urgent when he arrives in Dunwich on the Suffolk coast to find that his mother has aggressive throat cancer, and the â€œbeautiful house of his childhoodâ€ is about to be sold.Visiting her in hospital while she undergoes a tracheostomy, L-J becomes obsessed with how the choices he made as a young man might have changed the current family circumstances. His father left â€œsuddenly, clinically, for another womanâ€ when he was a boy, and now L-J takes on the burden of looking after his mother, clashing with his vulpine and self-centred sister, Ellie, and her boorish husband. As he keeps vigil by her bedside, heâ€™s forced to re-examine all of his certainties.The focus for his mental exploration is a piece of amber found on the beach during a walk with his mother. The idea that a naturally arising flaw â€“ â€œa succinosis, a cavity, a faultâ€ â€“ can allow ancient insects to be caught in a treeâ€™s resin helps him assimilate the fact of death. The glitch that caused his aeroplane to plummet, the seaâ€™s erosion of the coastline, his motherâ€™s tumour: all are part of lifeâ€™s hidden pattern of growth and decay. Holding the amber up to the light, â€œigniting the fiery dynamo withinâ€, he marvels that â€œsomething so beautiful â€¦ could be made out of a faultâ€.While Rourke doesnâ€™t hold back from the visceral horror of a long illness, there are moments of exquisite understanding between mother and son. When she talks of â€œthe beautiful intrusionâ€ of dust motes in a HammershÃ¸i painting, â€œmessing up the otherwise beautiful compositionâ€, it reinforces his belief that â€œthe best things, the things that speak to us the most, are the mistakesâ€. He must accept his motherâ€™s flaws and her inevitable passing, in order to love her completely.Occasionally overschematic with its central metaphor, Glitch is nonetheless an unflinching depiction of a son trying to solve the mystery of a parentâ€™s life, as well as coming to terms with his own contradictions. It is a wise and tender novel.â€¢ Jude Cookâ€™s second novel Jacobâ€™s Advice will be published by Unbound. Glitch is published by Dead Ink.

story: Your space to discuss the books you are reading and what you think of them Welcome to this weekâ€™s blogpost. A media pile on, led by a sleazy TV journalist, Richard Cody, convinces the country and the government and opposition that the Doll is a major terrorist, when all she has done is slept overnight with a young Arab, also mistakenly identified as a terrorist â€¦ what is truly disturbing about this book, set in the too-real sleaze and corruption of early 21st century Kings Cross, is that with the current overreach of Australiaâ€™s terror laws, which Flanagan brilliantly exposes, it could happen to any of us.Finally, NicolaVintageReads brings us an image to consider from Alexandra Fullerâ€™s new memoir Travel Light, Move Fast:â€˜Hippos often come up to the lawn in front of the pub to graze at night in any case, theyâ€™d dispensed with the need for a mower. â€˜Careful not to walk up a hipposâ€™s arse in the darkâ€™, Dad always warned if I left my barstool to venture into the pubâ€™s ablution block.â€™You may have read Fullerâ€™s earlier books, my favourite of which is Cocktail Hour Under the Tree of Forgetfulness, where she recalls coming of age in a family of white settlers in Zimbabwe in the early seventies.
